## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 368, 317]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 698]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 714]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 586, 94]]<|/det|>
The cubic equation \(7x^{3} + 3x^{2} + 5x + 1 = 0\) has roots \(\alpha , \beta , \gamma .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 571, 125]]<|/det|>
Find a cubic equation whose roots are \(\alpha^{-1}, \beta^{-1}, \gamma^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 361, 185, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 359, 430, 380]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^{-2} + \beta^{-2} + \gamma^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 358, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 602, 143, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 602, 430, 621]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\alpha^{-3} + \beta^{-3} + \gamma^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 602, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 710, 94]]<|/det|>
The sequence \(u_{1}, u_{2}, u_{3}, \ldots\) is such that \(u_{1} = 1\) and \(u_{n + 1} = 2u_{n} + 1\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 638, 123]]<|/det|>
Prove by induction that \(u_{n} = 2^{n} - 1\) for all positive integers \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 185, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 560, 504, 581]]<|/det|>
Deduce that \(u_{2n}\) is divisible by \(u_{n}\) for \(n \geqslant 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 562, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 92, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 428, 98]]<|/det|>
Let \(S_{n} = 2^{2} + 6^{2} + 10^{2} + \ldots +\left(4n - 2\right)^{2}.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 109, 144, 128]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 831, 129]]<|/det|>
Use standard results from the List of Formulae (MF19) to show that \(S_{n} = \frac{4}{3} n(4n^{2} - 1).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the invariant lines, through the origin, of the transformation in the \(x\)-\(y\) plane represented by **CAB**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 824, 96]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = a\tan \theta\) , where \(a\) is a positive constant and \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 702, 127]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) and state the greatest distance of a point on \(C\) from the pole.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 477, 146, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 477, 821, 497]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the area of the region bounded by \(C\) and the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 477, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 554, 102]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has Cartesian equation \(y = \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 186, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 537, 752, 571]]<|/det|>
Using your answer to part (b), deduce the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{2}a\sqrt{2}} \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}} \mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 460, 104]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{10 + x - 2x^2}{2x - 3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 545, 185, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 545, 428, 564]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) has no turning points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 678, 89]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of the intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 84, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 915, 102]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{10 + x - 2x^2}{2x - 3}\right|\) and find in exact form the set of values of \(x\) for

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
which \(\left|\frac{10 + x - 2x^2}{2x - 3}\right| < 4.\) [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
The lines \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) have equations \(\mathbf{r} = - 5\mathbf{j} + \lambda (5\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{k})\) and \(\mathbf{r} = 4\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k} + \mu (\mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k})\) respectively. The plane \(\varPi\) contains \(l_{1}\) and is parallel to \(l_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 724, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of \(\varPi\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 126, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 185, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 560, 440, 579]]<|/det|>
Find the distance between \(l_{2}\) and \(\varPi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 828, 92]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) on \(l_{1}\) and the point \(Q\) on \(l_{2}\) are such that \(PQ\) is perpendicular to both \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 798, 138]]<|/det|>
Show that \(P\) has position vector \(\frac{55}{27}\mathbf{i} - 5\mathbf{j} + \frac{25}{27}\mathbf{k}\) and state a vector equation for \(PQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 89]]<|/det|>
